raw_json.html_title: As the red line clearly demonstrates, â€¦ | R-bloggers
raw_json.main_html:
As the red line clearly demonstrates, â€¦

Posted on January 2, 2026 by Jerry Tuttle in R bloggers | 0 Comments

[This article was first published on Online College Math Teacher, and kindly contributed to R-bloggers]. (You can report issue about the content on this page here)
Want to share your content on R-bloggers? click here if you have a blog, or here if you don't.
Â Â Â Â Â  I have been at lots of business meetings where the speaker would say something like, â€œAs the red line clearly demonstrates, â€¦â€

Â Â Â Â Â  I would quickly look up at two particular co-workers. We all had that same rolling of the eyes look. When you have color-challenged issues, that red line does not clearly demonstrate anything to us. (And yes, the three of us knew we all had color issues.)

Â Â Â Â Â  I wrote the R code for this graph. But I used a random number to decide which line is red and which is green, so I donâ€™t know which line is which.

Â Â Â Â Â  I am not color-blind. I am color-challenged. I see some colors, but probably not as many as most people see. I donâ€™t distinguish between red and green well. I also donâ€™t distinguish between blue and purple well because of the red element of purple, and similarly for other combinations.

Â Â Â Â Â  In my earliest elementary school years I had a box of 8 Crayola crayons, and I did just fine. My problems began when Crayola started adding more and more colors including combinations like green yellow and yellow green. Here are the original eight colors, which I still identify just fine. (There is no meaning to the heights of the bars.)

Â Â Â Â Â  One source suggests approximately 1 in 12 men have color issues, but only 1 in 200 women.

Â Â Â Â Â  Color-challenged people often have coping strategies. I can see when the top traffic light is on, so I will stop my car. But in my heart, I donâ€™t think it is red, but more of an orange. Similarly I can see when the bottom traffic light is on, but I think it is more of an off-white than green. As long as no one flips the positions, I am fine. A single flashing light is a probllem though.

Â Â Â Â Â  When I see an 8-sided stop sign, thatâ€™s what I consider red. And I recognize Taylor Swift wears what I consider a very red lipstick, but I assume she wears more than one shade and I cannot distinguish among them.

Â Â Â Â Â  The speaker with the two-line graph could have used the different shapes, or different graph line types dashes and dots, in the talk. Or the speaker could have used color-blind friendly color palettes. If you are creating visualizations for others, please think about these things.

Â Â Â Â Â  And ladies, that purple lipstick looks very nie on you. Oh, itâ€™s not purple â€¦ ?

Â Â Â Â Â  The R code is as follows: 




# Two lines with random colors
x <- seq(1:5)
y <- seq(1:5)
z <- seq(5,1, by = -1)

color_1 <- "#00B050"
color_2 <- "#FF0000" 

r <- runif(1,0,1)
r
if (r < .5){
  col_y <- color_1
  col_z <- color_2
} else{
  col_y <- color_2
  col_z <- color_1
}

plot(x,y, type="b", pch = 18, cex = 2.5, lwd = 2.5, col=col_y, ylab="", xlab="", 
     main="As the red line clearly demonstrates ...", cex.main = 1.5,
     sub="If r
End

Related

As the red line clearly demonstrates, â€¦

I have been at lots of business meetings where the speaker would say something like, â€œAs the red line clearly demonstrates, â€¦â€
I would quickly look up at two particular co-workers.  We all had that same rolling of the eyes look. When you have color-challenged issues, that red line does not clearly demonstrate anything to us. (And yes, the three of us knew we all had color issues.)
I wrote the R code for this graph.  But I used a random number to decide which line is red and which is green, so I donâ€™t know which line is which.
I am not color-blind.  I am color-challenged.  I see some colors, but probably not as many as most people see.  I donâ€™t distinguish between red and green well.  I also donâ€™t distinguish between blue and purple well because of the red element of purple, and similarly for other combinations.
In my earliest elementary school years I had a box of 8 Crayola crayons, and I did just fine. My problems began when Crayola started adding more and more colors including combinations like green yellow and yellow green. Here are the original eight colors, which I still identify just fine. (There is no meaning to the heights of the bars.)
One
source
suggests approximately 1 in 12 men have color issues, but only 1 in 200 women.
Color-challenged people often have coping strategies. I can see when the top traffic light is on, so I will stop my car.  But in my heart, I donâ€™t think it is red, but more of an orange.  Similarly I can see when the bottom traffic light is on, but I think it is more of an off-white than green. As long as no one flips the positions, I am fine.  A single flashing light is a probllem though.
When I see an 8-sided stop sign, thatâ€™s what I consider red.  And I recognize Taylor Swift wears what I consider a very red lipstick, but I assume she wears more than one shade and I cannot distinguish among them.
The speaker with the two-line graph could have used the different shapes, or different graph line types dashes and dots, in the talk.  Or the speaker could have used color-blind friendly color palettes.  If you are creating visualizations for others, please think about these things.
And ladies, that purple lipstick looks very nie on you.  Oh, itâ€™s not purple â€¦ ?
The R code is as follows:
# Two lines with random colors
x <- seq(1:5)
y <- seq(1:5)
z <- seq(5,1, by = -1)

color_1 <- "#00B050"
color_2 <- "#FF0000" 

r <- runif(1,0,1)
r
if (r < .5){
  col_y <- color_1
  col_z <- color_2
} else{
  col_y <- color_2
  col_z <- color_1
}

plot(x,y, type="b", pch = 18, cex = 2.5, lwd = 2.5, col=col_y, ylab="", xlab="", 
     main="As the red line clearly demonstrates ...", cex.main = 1.5,
     sub="If r
End
